text: 1B P8: Bioengineering Ocular Biomechanics and Biomaterials Lecturer: Prof Yan Yan Shery Huang (yysh2) Biomechanics course outlines Define the problem When to apply Engineering & How to solve What is the broader impact 1. Tissues in the Eye - Normal eye anatomy - Composition and structure of tissues - Biomaterial mechanical properties 2. Structural and Fluid Mechanics - The eye as a shell - Flow of blood and aqueous humour - IOP; Modelling glaucoma 3. Disorder, Disease and Repair - Disorder in focal function - Contact and intraocular lenses - Cataracts, corneal opacity - Tissue engineering for eye repair 1 2 â€¢ Need to maintain shape to preserve optical properties. â€¢ Shape maintained by internal pressurisation - intraocular pressure (IOP). â€¢ Overall structure can be represented as a thin-walled spherical shell. â€¢ Wall properties given by sclera and cornea. â€¢ Structural features at cornea and at optic nerve omitted â€¢ Tissue property is linear elastic and time-independent â€¢ Model as a sphere with no bending stresses to give biaxial stresses: The eye as a pressurised shell h R p 2 = ï³ pR2ï° ï³ï°r2 R h [Model simplifications; assumptions] â€¢ Need to maintain shape to preserve optical properties. â€¢ Shape maintained by internal pressurisation - intraocular pressure (IOP). â€¢ Values of IOP (NB 1 mmHg = 133 Pa) - Normal = 15.5 mmHg - Changes with arterial pulse - Extreme = 50 mmHg - Loads due to accommodation (changing lens shape), blinking - Rubbing eyes, IOP ~80 mmHg. â€¢ Overall structure can be represented as a thin-walled spherical shell. h R p 2 = ï³ â€¢ Wall properties given by sclera and cornea. â€¢ Structural features at cornea and at optic nerve. â€¢ Model as a sphere with no bending stresses to give biaxial stresses: â€¢ e.g. p =15.5 mmHg, h = 0.78 mm, R = 12 mm, E = 3 MPa Implications: change in eye size during different loads, failure? pR2ï° ï³ï°r2 R h kPa 16=ï³ ( ) %26.0 2 1 =ï‚»âˆ’= EE ï³ ï® ï³ ï¥ Analyse the equation The eye as a pressurised shell [Model simplifications; assumptions] 3 4 â€¢ Rigidity important in understanding of measurement of IOP (tonometry), resistance to aqueous humour outflow, development of myopia (near sightedness), ocular pulse. â€¢ Assume linear relationship between biaxial wall stress ï³ and strain ï¥: Structure: Ocular rigidity â€¢ Change in volume V related to change in radius and strain: ( ) V E R h V IOP K V IOP 3 1 1 2 d d d d d )(d d )(d ïµ ï¥ ï¥ ï³ ï³ âˆ’ ==ï‚º â€¢ The coefficient of rigidity K characterises the effect of IOP on change in volume. It is a structural property, depending on geometry and material properties. ï¥ ï° d3 d3d 3 4 3 ==ïƒ= R R V VR V for small ï¥ ( ) E ïµï³ ï¥ âˆ’ = 1 â€¢ Wall stresses proportional to IOP as per shell calculation h R IOPh R IOP 2)(d d 2 =ïƒ= ï³ï³ neglecting second order change of R Cataract patients [Pallikaris 2004] K = 0.013Ã—35.7 mmHg/mL [For multiplication factor see Pallikaris 2006]â€¢ Typical values of h = 0.78mm, R = 12 mm, E = 3 MPa, ï® = 0.5, give K = 0.27 mmHg/mL, in good agreement with the measured value of 0.46 mmHg/mL. â€¢ Changes in IOP are implicated in disease, e.g. glaucoma. â€¢ Tonometry measures IOP indirectly by deformation of the cornea. â€¢ Direct measurement of pressure by e.g. pressure tapping not normally appropriate. Tonometry [Ethier and Simmons] https://vimeo.com/75806361 [Biomechanics as a diagnostic tool] 5 6 â€¢ Changes in IOP associated with elastic deformation and outflow of aqueous humour [Ethier and Simmons] â€¢ Goldmann tonometry: - anaesthetize cornea - place head on cornea with force W - flattened area A - IOP = W/A - correction needed for tear film and bending stresses - empirically noted that these cancel out when A = 7.35 mm2 - further correction for abnormal corneal thickness. Tonometry [Biomechanics as a diagnostic tool] Fluid: Fluids in the eye Fluid type: blood flow; aqueous humour; interstitial flow in ECM; â€¢ No vasculature in the lens and cornea to ensure transparency â€“ the aqueous humour nourishes these regions. â€¢ Blood transports oxygen and nutrients, taking away waste products. â€¢ Choroid has highest perfused volume of any tissue in body â€“ high metabolism needed to detect photons. â€¢ Interstitial fluids: fluids contained in all tissue spaces and pores 7 8 Blood flow in the eye â€¢ â€œStarling resistorâ€: - Pressure falls along vessel due to pipe friction â€¢ Unique blood flow system in eye. â€¢ Blood transports oxygen and nutrients, taking away waste products. â€¢ Choroid has highest perfused volume of any tissue in body â€“ high metabolism needed to detect photons. Artery pressure (e.g.75/35 mmHg) Venous pressure (8-10 mmHg) Blood flow Bernoulli's principle, rigid pipe [Model simplifications; assumptions] Blood flow in the eye â€¢ â€œStarling resistorâ€: - Pressure falls along vessel due to pipe friction - Collapse of blood vessel under external pressure causes constriction - Constriction controls flow, with no effect of downstream pressure on flow - Compares with supersonic throat or waterfall â€“ hence termed vascular waterfall - Net effect: flow controlled by IOP rather than venous pressure - Need to autoregulate flow to cope with differences in IOP. Artery pressure (e.g.75/35 mmHg) Venous pressure (8-10 mmHg) IOP (e.g.15.5 mmHg) â€¢ Unique blood flow system in eye. â€¢ Blood transports oxygen and nutrients, taking away waste products. â€¢ Choroid has highest perfused volume of any tissue in body â€“ high metabolism needed to detect photons. assumptions] 11 12 Microstructural interpretation - Intrinsic permeability k: h = fluid viscosity, 1 mPa s for water, 0.75 mPas for aqueous humour (NB h not fluids symbol of m to avoid confusion with friction). k has units of m2 and gives an estimate of internal surface areas covered by the pores â†’ the intrinsic pore size Pore sizes can be too small to see (nm) but can be measured mechanically Time constant: e.g. dimensional analysis Characterising poroelastic flow ï« ï´ E h2 = Darcyâ€™s Law for fluid flow: Q = rate of volume discharge across an area, A Î”p = pressure difference applied across specimen with thickness h ï« = hydraulic permeability [units m4 (Ns)-1] h pA Q )(ï„ = ï« hï«=k ğ‰ Step displacement inputStep pressure input Applying Darcyâ€™s Law (to understand disease mechanism) â€¢ Bruchâ€™s membrane is a five-layer barrier limiting transport between the choroid and the outer retina. â€¢ Water moves under the action of hydrostatic and osmotic pressure gradients. â€¢ Increase in hydraulic resistance with age a consequence of lipid accumulation, hypothesized to contribute to age-related macular degeneration by causing retinal detachment.Î”ğ‘ğ‘„/ğ´ =â„ğœ… 13 14 â€¢ Corneal drug delivery difficult. â€¢ Scleral drug delivery to retina may be attractive; need to check on transport rates. - Compare fluid transport in the opposite directions: due to convection flow (Darcyâ€™s law) vs. diffusional transport - Dimensional analysis Applying Darcyâ€™s Law (to guide drug delivery strategy) ğœ…Î”p (unit, m2/ s), Darcyâ€™s law D (unit, m2/ s), diffusion coefficient h = 7.5Ã—10-4Pa.s, Î”p=15 mmHg, intrinsic permeability k =2Ã—10-14cm2 [NB easiest to convert to SI units first, and check dimensions] https://doi.org/10.1016/0014-4835(77)90136-1 â†’ ğœ…Î”p~ 5Ã—10-12 m2/s â†’ ğ·~ 2Ã—10-10 m2/s to ~ 4Ã—10-13 m2/s ï« = hydraulic permeability [units m4 (Ns)-1] â€¢ Provides pressurisation of eye (source of IOP) â€¢ Nourishes cornea and lens â€¢ Clears debris from eye (e.g. red cells from haemorrhage) â€¢ Typical production rate of 2.4 mL/min â€“ 1% of volume of anterior chamber per minute, peak in morning, minimum at night Aqueous humour flow regulation Structure (anatomy) Loading conditions State of the material: functions, deformation, failure Material (living, reactive) Concept: Mechanobiology Source: https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-981-15-5632-6_2 [Ethier et al] ciliary muscle Production of aqueous humour drainage routes Thermal convection Schlemmâ€™s canal 15 16 Source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TgjdPgSxeYg; https://www.centreforsight.com/treatments/glaucoma-treatments-migs/hydrus Aqueous humour flow regulation â€¢ Typical production rate of 2.4 mL/min (by ciliary body) â€“ 1% of volume of anterior chamber per minute, peak in morning, minimum at night â€¢ Regulation needed to maintain IOP â€“ high IOP leads to glaucoma Aqueous humour [Ethier et al] ciliary muscle Production of aqueous humour drainage routes Thermal convection Schlemmâ€™s canal â€¢ Two drainage routes, principal route at conjunction of iris, cornea and sclera â€“ trabecular meshwork, and Schlemmâ€™s canal ğ‘„ Î”ğ‘ = ğœ…ğ´ â„ Resistance of 3-4 mmHg/(mL/min) Provided by: 1. Proteoglycan-rich gels in the trabecular meshwork (interstitial flow) 2. Endothelial lining of Schlemmâ€™s canal, bulging into the lumen of the canal (channel flow) Schlemmâ€™s canal 17 18 â€¢ High IOP implicated in glaucoma â€¢ How could aqueous humour flow be controlled to regulate IOP? â€¢ Experiments show an immediate increase in IOP with increased perfusion of media. â€¢ IOP then returns to baseline after 150 hours. â€¢ Perfusate collected from experiments contained increased gelatinase A (MMP-2). â€¢ Suggests that ECM material is linked to control of IOP. Aqueous humour liquid drainage: control of IOP [Ethier, Barocas & Crawford Downs/Bradley et al Provided by: 1. proteoglycan-rich gels in the trabecular meshwork (interstitial flow) 2. endothelial lining of Schlemmâ€™s canal, bulging into the lumen of the canal. Auto-regulation â€¢ Large arteries adjust their diameter over time (remodelling) in reaction to the wall shear stress (WSS). WSS sensed by endothelial cells lining the artery â€“ mechanotransduction. Flow After stenosis (low WSS) At stenosis/constriction in aorta (high WSS) Aqueous humour liquid drainage: control of IOP Provided by: (i) proteoglycan-rich gels in the trabecular meshwork (ii) endothelial lining of Schlemmâ€™s canal, bulging into the lumen of the canal. (channel flow) Endothelial cell lining Difficult to study for Schlemmâ€™s canalâ€¦ but we can do estimate Source: https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-981-15-5632-6_2 19 20 â€¢ Large arteries adjust their diameter over time (remodelling) in reaction to the wall shear stress (WSS). WSS sensed by endothelial cells lining the artery â€“ mechanotransduction. â€¢ Typical WSS in the range 2-20 dynes/cm2 [1 dyne = 10-5 N, from CGS = cmâ€“g â€“s units] â€¢ Assume laminar Poiseuille flow, governed by viscous forces (Reynoldâ€™s number is small as the vessels are so small). See 1B Fluids lectures. Take, e.g. Q = 0.24 mL/min, h = 7.5Ã—10-4 Pa.s, W = 260 mm, h = 5 mm ïƒ tf = 2.7 dynes/cm2 â€¢ Mechanism supported by preferential alignment of endothelial cells in Schlemmâ€™s canal. How mechanics are indicated in disease: glaucoma Source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TgjdPgSxeYg; https://www.centreforsight.com/treatments/glaucoma-treatments-migs/hydrus 21 22 Mechanics of Glaucoma: IOP induced optic nerve head (ONH) damage â€¢ Hypothesised that high IOP is implicated in damage to the ONH causing glaucoma. â€¢ The lamina cribrosa (LC) is a porous connective tissue filling the ONH through which the nerve passes. â€¢ ONH acts as a stress concentration in the sclera allowing exit of the optic nerve. â€¢ Evidence suggests that damage to the ganglion nerve cells is associated with the LC. â€¢ Can we model what are the factors controlling deformation of the LC? Lamina cribrosa, neural cells digested away Mechanics of Glaucoma â€¢ Significant deformation of LC due to IOP seen in experiments â€¢ Models hampered by uncertainty in material properties. â€¢ Results from finite element (FE) analysis highlight importance of scleral modulus. Finite element model [Sigal and Ethier] Deformation of LC (Yan) 5 mmHg IOP 50 mmHg IOP 120 mm 1200 mm IOP lamina cribrosa 23 24 Structural mechanics of the LC: Plane membrane model â€¢ Strains of 5-8% can induce changes in neuronal cells. Can these strains arise in the LC? â€¢ Assume that modulus of LC is much less than that of the sclera (c.f. foams, relative density r*/rs =0.1 ïƒ E*/Es = 10-3) â€¢ Biaxial remote stresses. No radial stress at LC interface. â€¢ Assume that the in-plane stretch of LC is determined by stretch of surrounding sclera ( ) r rrl l EE ï¥ ï® ï¥ï³ï³ ï¥ 4 1 22 ï‚» âˆ’ === Hence ï¥l ï‚» 1% (see earlier calculation for ï¥r) for normal IOP Circumference of LC expands by 1%. All strains in the LC are 1%.
